Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

In the western United States, water is sometimes diverted from mountain streams and rivers to be used for agriculture and municipal water supplies. Diverting too much water raises the water temperature in the mountain streams and rivers, affecting the fish that live there.

A certain mountain river is abundant in brown trout and has water diverted from it for city use. Assume that the water temperature along all locations of the river has a distribution with mean <math alttext="18 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation of <math alttext="2 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A sport-fishing group plans to measure the water temperature at <math alttext="64" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> randomly selected locations along the river. Let the random variable <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean water temperature, in degrees Celsius, of <math alttext="64" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>64</mn></math> locations along the river selected at random by the sport-fishing group.
(a) Describe the distribution of <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Fish, such as brown trout, become stressed once water temperatures exceed <math alttext="18.3 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18.3</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Determine the probability <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will exceed <math alttext="18.3 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18.3</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show your work.

A large metropolitan water district that uses water diverted from the same river is also planning to measure the water temperature at <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> randomly selected locations along the river. Because of sampling variability, the sample collected by the water district is likely to yield a sample mean water temperature different from the sample mean water temperature collected by the sport-fishing group. Let the random variable <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean water temperature, in degrees Celsius, of <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn></math> locations along the river selected at random by the large metropolitan water district.
(c) Describe the distribution of <math alttext="D minus F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
